Setup

## Loading all the data files
## DO NOT CHANGE THIS CODE
championships <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_championships.tsv")
competitions <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Competitions.tsv")
continents <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Continents.tsv")
countries <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Countries.tsv")
eligible_country_iso2s_for_championship <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_eligible_country_iso2s_for_championship.tsv")
events <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Events.tsv")
formats <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Formats.tsv")
persons <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Persons.tsv")
ranksaverage <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_RanksAverage_333.tsv")
rankssingle <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_RanksSingle_333.tsv")
results <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_Results_333.tsv")
roundtypes <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_data/WCA_export_RoundTypes.tsv")
#scrambles <- read_tsv("WCA_data/WCA_export_Scrambles_333.tsv")
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(RColorBrewer)

# Rename personId in Results to id to match with Persons
Results_new <- results |>
  rename(id = personId)

# Clean duplicates from both tables
results_cleaned <- Results_new |>
  distinct(id, eventId, .keep_all = TRUE)  # Keep the best result per person per event

persons_cleaned <- persons |>
  distinct(id, .keep_all = TRUE)  # Ensure unique persons

# Join persons with cleaned results based on the 'id' column
joined_data <- left_join(persons_cleaned, results_cleaned, by = "id")


# Clean the data to only keep 'value1' (best solve time in centiseconds) and 'gender'
plot_data <- joined_data |>
  select(gender, value1) |>
  filter(!is.na(gender), !is.na(value1))  # Remove NAs for gender and value1

# Convert centiseconds to seconds (divide by 100)
plot_data <- plot_data |>
  mutate(value1_seconds = value1 / 100)  # Convert to seconds


# If you see any unexpected categories, you can filter them out
plot_data <- plot_data |>
  filter(gender %in% c("m", "f"))

# Create the violin plot with adjusted limits and using a log scale if necessary
ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = gender, y = value1_seconds)) +
  geom_violin(aes(fill = gender), alpha = 0.7, trim = TRUE) +  # Trim the outliers
  labs(title = "Best Single Solve Time by Gender (Seconds)",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Best Solve Time (Seconds)") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +  # Use a more appealing color palette
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::number_format(scale = 1), 
                     limits = c(0, quantile(plot_data$value1_seconds, 0.95))) +  # Limit y-axis to 95th percentile of the data
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, quantile(plot_data$value1_seconds, 0.95)))  # Dynamically adjust limits
Warning: Removed 22843 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_ydensity()`).

Second plot code (Group member 2)

# Joining the datasets by participants' name
merged_data <- persons |> 
  inner_join(results, by = c("name" = "personName"), relationship = "many-to-many")
# Counting the number of competitors per country to identify Top 10 Performing Countries
top_countries <- merged_data |> 
  count(countryId, sort = TRUE) |> 
  top_n(10, n)
# Filtering merged_data for top 10 countries that we identified previously
filtered_data <- merged_data |> 
  filter(countryId %in% top_countries$countryId)

# Converting countryId to a factor for ordered plotting
filtered_data <- filtered_data |> 
  mutate(countryId = factor(countryId, levels = top_countries$countryId))

# Creating box plots for showcasing average scores 
ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x = countryId, y = average, fill = countryId)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Comparison of Average Scores Across Top 10 Countries", 
       x = "Country", 
       y = "Average Score") +
  theme_minimal()
# Filtering out outliers using the interquartile range (IQR)
Q1 <- quantile(filtered_data$average, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE)
Q3 <- quantile(filtered_data$average, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)
IQR_value <- Q3 - Q1

# Defining lower and upper bounds
lower_bound <- Q1 - 1.5 * IQR_value
upper_bound <- Q3 + 1.5 * IQR_value

# Filtering data to remove extreme outliers
filtered_no_outliers <- filtered_data |> 
  filter(average >= lower_bound & average <= upper_bound)

# Plot the cleaned data
ggplot(filtered_no_outliers, aes(x = countryId, y = average, fill = countryId)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.shape = NA) +  # Remove outlier points
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Comparison of Average Scores Across Top 10 Countries", 
       x = "Country", 
       y = "Average Score") +
  theme_minimal()

Blog Post Here

Our research question: What is the average performance score (based on solving time) across top 10 performing countries and across genders in the World Cube Association?

Context of the dataset Speedcubing is a highly competitive activity that requires both mental agility and dexterity, with events held globally under the World Cube Association (WCA). In our analysis, we wanted to explore how performance varies across gender and the top 10 performing countries in speedcubing. By focusing on solve times (for the violin graph value 1, and for the boxplots using the average), we sought to determine whether there were notable differences between male and female competitors and how national averages compared.

The violin plot presents a comparative distribution of best single solve times for male (m) and female (f) competitors. Each “violin” represents the density of data points, showing where solve times are most concentrated. A wider section of the violin indicates more competitors achieving that solve time, while narrower sections highlight less frequent results.The data showed that for this set, males tend to achieve faster times overall. The male distribution is more compressed at the lower end (faster solve times), suggesting a higher concentration of top performers. The female distribution is wider and skewed towards slower times. The female violin has a greater spread, with a noticeable presence at higher solve times (closer to 100 seconds). This suggests that female competitors, on average, take longer to complete a solve. Both distributions have outliers. Some competitors, regardless of gender, achieve extreme solve times. However, the shape of the male distribution suggests a larger proportion of highly competitive times. Performance variation differs between genders. The male distribution is more tightly clustered, indicating relatively consistent performance among male competitors, whereas the female distribution is broader, suggesting a wider range of abilities among female competitors. The findings imply that male and female speedcubing competitors perform differently, but this should not be taken as evidence of a difference in biological ability. These differences may be caused by a number of outside factors.Participation Rates: Historically, more men have participated in speedcubing, which has expanded the pool of competitors and, as a result, produced more elite performances.Training and Representation: Performance outcomes may be impacted by unequal access to coaching, training materials, and competitive experience between the sexes. Sociocultural Influences: Participation and performance may be impacted by variations in social expectations, exposure to competitive contexts, and encouragement.

Using boxplots allowed us to visualize the range of average scores across the top-performing countries, highlighting the median as well as the lower and upper bounds of participant scores worldwide. The boxplots indicate that countries like Germany, Poland, and China have a narrower range of results, whereas Spain, Canada, and Australia exhibit broader variations. When looking at median values, Spain, Canada, and India rank among the top three, which may correlate with their wider result distributions.

However, it’s important to consider the context behind these averages. The number of reported results varies significantly across countries, affecting representation. For instance, the U.S. recorded nearly 400,000 observations, while China had around 126,000. In contrast, most other countries had between 40,000 and 80,000 recorded results. This disparity suggests that some countries, like the U.S., may offer more opportunities for participation, lowering barriers to entry and encouraging beginners—potentially leading to a lower national average solve time. Meanwhile, countries with fewer beginner-friendly competitions may have higher national averages due to a more selective competitive environment. This factor warrants further investigation.

Key Takeaways and Ethical Considerations

Our analysis suggests that speedcubing performance varies significantly across genders and countries, with external factors playing a substantial role. When merging datasets across different demographics and regions, ethical considerations arise—especially in ensuring fair representation. Differences in sample sizes, accessibility to competitions, and sociocultural influences must be accounted for to avoid misleading conclusions. Understanding these nuances is crucial for conducting fair and insightful analyses.
